Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF CAREER
Policy for low-carbon technology investment: A comparative international perspective on emerging economy responses to climate change

Dr. Nathan E. Hultman
School of Public Policy
University of Maryland
December 2010

This research and teaching agenda will probe the motivations for emerging economy firms to invest and innovate in low-carbon technology. The central research question of this proposal is: How do firms in emerging economies respond to international and domestic energy policies when making low-carbon investment decisions? The research will evaluate the differences in deployment and international policy participation in solar photovoltaic and wind electricity generation in India, Brazil, South Africa, and South Korea. Through field research and interviews, the investigators will assess the major policy influences for low-carbon investment decisions in these countries and technologies. This work will contribute to scholarship on firm decisionmaking in response to energy policies. It can also potentially inform the approach of national and international low-carbon technology policy. Through courses and research experience, this proposal encourages students to link technology outcomes with policy drivers; to develop an informed, comparative international perspective on technology investments; and to engage with this important policy discourse in the US and internationally.
Reducing emissions that lead to climate change will be a paramount task in the 21st Century. Limiting global average surface temperature increases to approximately 2ÂºC would entail global emissions cuts of at least 50?85% by 2050. Moreover, over the next quarter-century, over 95% of the growth in global emissions will occur in the non-OECD economies. Investment flows in these countries into the energy sector will dwarf those in all other world regions: in just the period to 2030, energy investment in the largest emerging economies will constitute nearly 60% of the world total?over $10 trillion. Any policy that seeks to reduce global emissions must therefore be informed by the factors driving investment in these areas. Furthermore, climate policy is likely moving toward a regime of parallel domestic policies that are coordinated and reported internationally. Because of the complexity of this new interaction, understanding investment decisions in response to both domestic and international policies will be a key to evaluating a successful and sufficiently ambitious long-term international approach to transitioning to a low-carbon economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, "Policy for low-carbon technology investment: A comparative international perspective on emerging economy responses to climate change" established a comprehensive and integrated program of research, education, and impact that (1) identifies and refines our understanding of the policy and investment drivers of low-carbon investment decisions at national and international levels and (2) applies that understanding to informing policy creation at the international, national, and sub-national levels. It did this in three ways.

First, it supported a broad research program by the PI focusing on low-carbon technologies, policy, and investment decisionmaking. The primary research focus supported by this grant investigated firm responses to domestic and international policy in solar and wind technology investment in four important emerging economy countries (India, Brazil, South Korea, and South Africa). These countries were carefully selected because they have relatively similar, democratic governance structures and were all undergoing periods of rapid economic expansion. A core focus of this project was to build a better understanding of how national and international policies differentially influence investments in renewable energy deployment. This research formed the core around which the educational and impact elements of the project could be built, and the basis for additional and complementary funded research, including work focusing on applications within the United States.

Second, the project supported a development of an integrated educational program that links teaching and student research. This program was targeted at (1) developing new courses and course materials that teach students about relationships between policy (at all governance levels), development of new technologies, and how those can be used to inform policies that can reach societal goals relating to pollution, jobs, development, and climate change; (2) providing opportunities for students in our professional Masters of Public Policy program to gain exposure to these processes in important emerging economies, and to use that knowledge to inform their public service work in the United States, in the State of Maryland, other states in the Nation, or in international or other contexts; (3) supporting the development of research expertise for Ph.D. students and postdoctoral fellows, and generating research ideas and methods for them to integrate into their dissertation, joint publications, and subsequent careers. 

Third, the project supported a program of broader impact, informed by the research and educational components. This was accomplished not only through academic routes (publications, conferences) but also via communication and dialogue with the policy community at national and international levels.

This integrated program has produced a number of project outcomes. First, the core project was the basis for to the founding of a new cross-disciplinary research group and the research insights and methods led to the founding of a new research center at the University of Maryland. It has also led to a book manuscript and seven published papers on topics related to national policies for energy technology deployment. Five Ph.D. dissertations have been informed by this work. 

This project has had an impact in research, education, and broader society. First, there is a research contribution specifically on the inquiry informed by the four-country comparative case appraoch. Our approach on that dimension was, and still is, largely unique, in structuring a cross-country comparative study in emerging economies to investigate similarities and differences in the impact of domestic and international policies on renewable deployment. The insights from that component indicate the necessity of multi-layered signals for deployment--from multiple levels of governance and from private sector collaborations--to ensure rapidity and longevity of investment effort.

The second contribution is on education and training. Insights from the research were integrated into three courses taught by the PI -- a class on energy policy, on climate policy, and on practicing public policy. These courses were pitched at both professional masters students in Public Policy and also to research-oriented Ph.D. students. In addition, the project directly engaged three Ph.D. students and a number of masters students. Seven of nine students closely engaged in the research and writing were women, in a field that tends to be skewed towards men. 

A third contribution is the development of a process to understand policy effort across countries in a compartive context, and integrate it with quantitative insights. This approach is central to the new international interest in assessing potential energy technology deployment and the processes to encourage low-carbon energy in specific national circumstances. These methods are quickly evolvoing, and the process is defining a set of methods and theoretical approaches that are establishing a new practice that bridges research and policy demand.
